Africa just has a bad reputation, maybe the worst in the world, when it comes to economic and educational issues. Maybe this is what in part perpetuates their problems for far longer than in other parts of the world even in cases where the countries make huge efforts to do better. Simply put, investors would feel much safer putting their money on a recovering European country than on an African one. It's like when a student that gets bad grades makes an effort to improve but finds himself stuck because the teachers already have a bad impression of him and don't trust that he will maintain his new-found motivation. This in turn gives the student worse results than he deserved, or at least than what he would have gotten with the same help from teachers that is considered universal, and so when the student actually feels discouraged, the teacher feels reassured in that his hunch had been right all along. It's a never ending cycle. The same affects African governments. If a government, especially in Africa, makes tremendous changes in an effort to repair their situation, when those changes don't pay off as expected, the government will face instability and might even be toppled.

Fun Fact: my geography teacher told me this to speak about the flaws of top-down aid. Some field workers were deployed in Africa, but didn’t know how to speak the language where they were deployed. The field first goal was to introduce contraceptives to the people in the village, not only to curve population but also HIV/AIDS in the area. To show how to use it, they did the banana-condom demonstration. The workers did this, but a few weeks later, HIV/AIDS hadn’t changed, in-fact, it had increased. They didn’t know why, it should have decreased. It was only when a field worker saw a basket of bananas with condoms to figure out the problem. The locals didn’t know that the banana was an analogy,  because they didn’t know the language, so they thought placing condoms on bananas helped with AIDS/HIV. Luckily, the field workers corrected this and the HIV/AIDS rate plummeted.

In Eastern Europe and far east Asia, some.countries have very low GDP per capita and very low fertility rate.
In Soviet Union, the fertility rate was sinking when the economy and life expectancy were sinking too.

On the opposite some countries had a recent increase of their fertility rate despite economic growth (Egypt, Nigeria...).

The gap between countries regarding fertility rates strongly depends on cultural and political factors.

The takeaway I get from this:
1. High birth rates are a reaction to adverse conditions rather than a cause. Lower life expectancy and higher infant mortality incentivize having more children and having them earlier.
2. Successful development of infrastructure to improve quality of life will thus reduce the advantages that high birth rates grant, making a lower birth rate and fewer children more advantageous to families.
3. Thus, a family planning program undertaken without an improvement to general infrastructure and quality of life will not resolve the conditions that make high birth rates advantageous.

This has an interesting implication: it would thus be possible for a development program that places too much emphasis on family planning, without addressing the social problems that encourage high birth rates, to be actively hazardous to a population. If such a circumstance develops, you would have a situation where it's still advantageous to have children early and often, yet a social pressure to avoid doing so, and thus long-term potential for a population to go into a deadly decline if infrastructure is not improved via other development programs.

Given the history of eugenics and its weaponization in the past, I would not be surprised if this could be a real worry that some people in developing countries might have, and I wonder what the risk is that it might be attempted, if it hasn't been considered by people with ill intent already.

This was a good video, but I think you're still framing this the wrong way. Africa's population boom isn't necessarily a problem that needs to be fixed, it could be a great opportunity, and in fact it's both of these things at once. In 2100, one in three people will be Africans. Africa's population is incredibly young, and could be the most important workforce in the world, if African countries make the right investments and moves in infrastructure (especially modernizing agriculture), education and removing trade barriers, Africa could have an economic boom similar to China's. But at the same time, this booming population without sufficient job creation could create a generation of angry, radicalized young men that could create problems. Thinking about the future of work without thinking about Africa is crazy. Next to climate change, the development of African countries and economies is probably the most important issue in the 21st century.

Here’s a fundamental lesson from biology, Outbreaks in nature don’t end well
Put a couple of protozoa into a Petri dish, they eat & reproduce, eat & reproduce, until BANG!
They hit the edge of the Petri dish, at which point they either drown in their own waste or starve from lack of resources.
The outbreak ends. From the viewpoint of biology, You & I are not fundamentally different then the protozoa in the Petri dish. We are an Outbreak species, [and unless we make drastic changes now] we’re going to hit the edge of the petri dish, simple as that.

Africa is actually quite big, Second largest continent, with 1.12 billion people? I think we can handle a high capacity population. People don't need to be educated on civics and such. Technology education works wonderfully for us. With vertical farming, we can feed more people sustainably. With vertical housing, we can house more people sustainably, with medicare research, we can have longer useful life out of the humans we invest in. We are the oldest human culture on earth, our cultural systems evolve to enable our survival in the most positive way possible. The idea of family planning is good, but it is unlikely to work here. Not because people are ignorant, but because everyone is always trying to have the best of the genepool. We have had heat based vasectomy down to a science for years, we have had cycle based contraception for centuries. The only difference between then and now, is the proliferation of STDs. In the past, those with STDs died off, and the diseases died with them; now they don't.

The final thing? Well, we don't forget or forgive easily. So the nations that colonized our lands and forbearers, are not allowed to have a say in how we conduct ourselves. To us, the world is full of enemies, and we can either burn them, or use them and block them out.

You've tiptoed around the effect of kleptocracy.

Colonial powers handed over "people that they owned" to governments that they felt "they could do business with". Since then, a lot of the business done with African countries has been done corruptly - one elite hand washing the other.

Just as the venal impulses of the colonies were replaced with business by bribery, so the paternalistic/ benevolent aspect of the colony was replaced with aid. And aid has continued to have an element of being aid to the donor country (fair enough, since it's the donor country's money; but that's not the way it's sold by those doing PR for it). Aid often involves things like providing nice jobs for children of the donor country, sent to tell the natives how to do something (and maybe finish a postgrad degree in the process); then the youngster employed with the donor country's own money (fair enough) goes home at the end of the project, and effectively hands it over to some local elite - ultimately descended from that initial government the previous colonial power could "do business with", back in the day, so the goals of management change (often toward diverting money wasted on the paternalistic aspects of the project to worthwhile things like the management's own family).

I'm being perhaps a bit cynical, but only as a "universal generalization". There are many cases in which scenarios like the above, and Worse, have been the lot of the people of Africa, more than anywhere else on Earth.

And whenever these messy parts of the whole picture start to show, and the blinkers are put on (because if you speak bluntly about things like this, you're a Bad Person), it just feeds back into one of the many vicious circles spinning around in Africa.

Yes, Africa is big, but there are some generalizations that have quite wide applicability.

Perhaps a better new way forward which would best help the people of Africa would be to withdraw aid from those countries that most clearly have "owners", rather than governments (that serve), and to divert it exclusively to those countries that are doing well, fixing their own problems. Perhaps make this diversion of support conditional on something in the direction of open borders, so that well-functioning countries can become havens that the ordinary people from misgoverned countries could flee to without causing detrimental social upheavals.

And then the messiness returns. If you withdraw your subsidy of that misgoverned country's elite, you create a vacuum that your rivals can fill up. Your own interests are best served by ... "governments you can do business with" (in other words, bribe). Still, in its broader terms, a policy that favoured "fundamental success" (accountable governments with sound policies effectively implemented and protected from destructive influences like those who offer bribes) would surely be better than just seeking maximum diplomatic advantage? (If any aspect of current policy is honestly focused on anything beyond that, I mean - which I'm assuming it must at least to some extent be).

You made the point that there are 3 main areas which can be addressed: 1) Education, 2) Infant / Child Mortality, and 3) Contraception [or, more generally, Family Planning. To really help Africa develop, I think we should follow the example of Botswana and their first President and Prime Minister (the monarchy was abolished a year-ish after he took office) Sir Seretse Khama. He instituted strong checks and balances with an independent and strong judiciary, meaning his country didn’t fall prey to the paradoxical resources curse. He liberalized the economy from an early stage with stable corporate and business taxes, bringing in foreign investment. He then used money from these ventures to strengthen the countries agriculture, and set organizations like Botswana Meat Commission. He negotiated contracts with foreign mining and drilling companies to set up joint ventures to bring in extra money. He used this surplus money to build schools, pave roads, and build hospitals to uplift the people of Botswana. He also didn’t make the mistakes that the white minority and socialists regimes of Africa did. He didn’t suppress talent based on race for the civil service, but didn’t immediately indigenize the bureaucracy by throwing out competent bureaucrats because of race. His policies were so successful, that the government was running a budget surplus just one year into his second term in 1970. FOLLOW HIS EXAMPLE

And during the same time the post-industrial economies will all be facing the problems that come with having a birth rate below 2.1 per woman (replacement rate). The only reason the Western powers aren't shrinking yet is immigration, which create a lot of problems of its own (cultural, social, economic). If you don't replace your population naturally or allow for immigration, you end up in Japan's situation (-0,5 mil in pop. just this year). That is: an inverted demographic pyramid. This means that fewer and fewer young adults will have to take care of more and more (in relative terms) old people who can't longer contribute to society. It's very unstable and taxing on the economy, with a risk of causing severe stagnation or even reversal of prosperity (which leads to political unrest). Not to mention the effects of de-urbanization and creation of ghost towns etc...

Subsaharan Africa is not a "made up idea". It's a politically correct term for talking about "Black Africa", that is the parts of Africa that have been inhabited by black people since time immemorial, juxtaposed against North Africa which has been inhabited by lighter skinned peoples such as the Berbers, Arabs, Copts, and so forth. Civil wars, government corruption, and the like don't explain the entirety of their situation. The same divergent evolution in humans that produced a variety of skin tones, eye shapes, hair textures, disease resistances, bone density, etc. also produced differences in the brain. There are bound to be differences in temperament, time preference, and intelligence. Intelligence can be viewed as "general intelligence" or divided into multiple categories such as mathematical, linguistic, kinesthetic, etc. Regardless of the number of categories there are going to be differences between the average mental attributes of any two populations.


Colonialism actually increased Africa's material wealth, not that I think material wealth is a good argument for colonialism. There is an innate desire in all peoples to have things their way, to make their own destiny without a bunch of outsider busy-bodies telling them how to run their own affairs. An individual, and oftentimes even entire groups of people can decide that trading self-ownership for subservience, and some material gain is not worth it. Fortunately for the Subsaharan Africans, their lower average intelligence is not just a curse. In some cases it can be a boon. This will make it harder to sell them on antinatalism and other destructive "big-brained" ideas that have taken hold in other parts of the world. High intelligence might grant a greater capacity for logic, but this also gives a greater capacity for bending one's thinking into mind-pretzels so as to justify bad ideas.

I love this channel and think that global development is important to talk about, but as much as you may say "sorry for making generalizations we needed to in order to fit the video length," I still resent the idea from the get-go that what should be focused on is population growth and "overpopulation" in these areas. Until we are at a point where we as humanity on planet earth do not have the resources to adequately feed ourselves, we should not point to overpopulation as something that is hindering us: when we say "overpopulation" in this way, what youre actually implying is that "africa" is only allowed a certain quota of people because we dont want to distribute resources in such a way that would allow them to have a larger population. In reality, the most pressing issue facing these developing countries is the intrusive and predatory nature of global capital, stripping away the countries natural resources, labor for internal development, educated population, etc. for the benefit of first world countries. The problem here in Africa is the education and the people's way of life because of it. Some people don't believe in it and instead become lazy and want everything for free without working. I am not trying to offend anyone, that is just my view from living in South Africa my whole life.

For example we have a lot of people who are not happy with the way our government leads our country , rightfully so. But then they just elect the same government party to lead , even though they only made things worse.
Others are also unhappy and expect it to change , but then they don't even go vote.

Back to education, we recently had a few strikes about education. Many people wanted new schools to be built and it is a good idea ,but what do they do to show that they're unhappy about the current education status?
They burn down another 4 schools...

It's problems like these that make Africa the way it is today, people make rash decisions , uneducated decisions and suffer the consequences therefore.

Take for example the high birthrate - There are loads of informal settlements (plakkerskampe) here is ZA with a lot of people living in them. The easiest solution to get out of those settlements is to have a lot of children.
More children mean the chances are higher that at least one will succeed , get an education and make a living.

And even when that one succeeds , he/she has to care for their family (brothers ,sisters, parents, uncle) of at least 10 people or more. Making it impossible to achieve higher.

There are also people who own a large portion of the country , mainly farmers, who get murdered because of racism, lowering the amount of food the country can produce.

Something to add to racism , at least a quarter of the country's population want to murder eachother , because one race wants the other to give them back their land which was stolen (but actually bought) in colonial times and also go back to where they came from.

We also recently began having something called "load shedding" , where we run without power for a few hours a day , because we put uneducated people at the lead of our power production, who made uneducated decisions and stole a massive amount of money from the country and in return cost it even more.

All of this applies to ZA , and might not apply to other African countries , many actually fight for their very existence because of poverty caused by the lack of education.

So to sum it up . The problem here in Africa is not stupid people it's the uneducated bad decisions , racism , corruption and horrible leaders caused by the lack of education.

The words "fair investment" stick in my ear like a pickaxe used to mine conflict minerals. Neocolonial "investment" on the continent is the source of most of the troubles referenced here. "Look!" they say, "we've improved so much in Africa because we're just so generous!" Meanwhile they make returns off the "boosted economy" (read trade liberalization and tax cuts for international firms), improved infrastructure, and a more educated workforce. Not to mention the boost to PR.

But what of it? It's a win-win isn't it? First of all, no, but also, consider that the power to make such generous gifts to the struggling masses of South Africa was only available because Microsoft made its money partially off of the cheap labor and resources of Africans. Steal from the poor, then give some of it back and get a fucking medal for your altruism. But that's capitalism for you, I guess.

I'll put it bluntly: it is not the purview of the fucking colonizer to diagnose social problems of the colonized people. The fact that white people half way across the world get to decide when population growth is a "problem" for Africa, instead of Africans themselves, is bad enough. Like it's ripped right out of a manuscript from Malthus himself, and oh! Here's a video uncritically espousing that idea without even mentioning the perspectives or wishes of the actual people of Africa.

Look, maybe Africans would decide that what they need is a reduction in birth rates - regardless, the power to affect such changes should be in their hands and used at their discretion, not delivered from on high by some white savior, in such a way that ensures his interests are protected. Furthermore, the whine from this channel about this being a complex topic does not excuse approaching the issue with a colonialist, white supremacist lense, which it absolutely does. I like this channel and this video very much, however; the premise presumes that population growth necessarily precludes economic success. It is much more interesting to me to imagine a continent full of young educated people as the largest demographic. With modern technology it is totally feasible to educate the masses relatively inexpensively. I can imagine that feeding a large population would be tough, but not impossible. I have heard from some very smart sources, including African expats, that Africa doesn't have a food production issue it has a food distribution issue. In the video it frames the education of women as a means to an end instead of an end in itself.  Educate women because it is good in the now. Their children in turn, will be educated by them, and be good in the future. Even if the population growth rate doesn't decline in the predicted way, then very well because now there's a larger population of educated peoples. The utilitarian-esque view point that you have to maximize quality of life while also necessarily minimizing quantity of lives is silent on the very real possibility that you can maximize both to a point. Of course earth's resources are finite but it seems to me a little backwards to employ population control before attempting to optimize resource usages, including human resources. Basically, I'm advocating for taking into account maximum population growth and planning to optimizing all those new people (aka new producers and consumers). Because no matter what, if we have the max number of people or the minimum, they will be of maximum quality.

Tyre continents of the would have showed time and again the same growth pattern. An initial population held back by limited economy focuses on a high birth rate for survival and growth. Eventually the economy stabilizes improving health and the living standards of the population. The ability to move from basic survival to triving lets the population turn to higher order needs like comfort and happiness which leads to reforms of older systems that were tolerated due to the need to survive. This eventually includes women who typically start out as..to be blunt..baby factories in the early days.

Better health leads to a baby boom as the large birth rate isn't countered by a large death rate. and more freedoms leads to the population choosing (or sadly being forced to) have less children. The birth rate then drops. We're yet to see a country avoid this or reverse it even when the country tries to do so.

This video, like all of Kurzgesagt's content, is clearly well researched and well made. But there is a dark undertone to this one which I'm surprised to find. Throughout the video, we are implicitly taken to understand that a lower population in Africa is a good thing, and that either of the projected population numbers given at the beginning are 'overpopulation'. This isn't explained or justified. Instead, the idea of African births, African children, African lives, are just linked directly to problems.
If the projected population numbers are expected to lead to a lower quality of life, then that needs to be stated and explained. If there are good reasons to think that sub-Saharan Africans would benefit from lower birth rates, give them. Without those reasons and justifications, we are left with an argument which just seems... a bit racist.

comment_text:
I went on a trip to South Africa and Namibia in early 2018. Many things were similar to my home - the African people acted much like Canadian people, the cities looked very similar, many of their customs were similar. But one thing that was really shocking to me was the sexual culture.

Children became sexually active at strikingly young ages in Namibia. Some of the girls I talked to were only 10. It wasn't abnormal for 13-year-old girls to fall pregnant. When I spoke to these girls, it seemed as though sex was an expectation: "I want to make my boyfriend happy, so we have sex." It was as if they feared their partners would leave them if they didn't become sexual. At the same time, awareness of contraception was not very high at all - a huge portion of the population had contracted and was dying from AIDS.

Many of these girls would have a child by 18 - for some, even more than one. The school drop-out rates were sky-high, especially for young girls. Graduating from elementary school was seen as a huge accomplishment for all genders. Rarely did any of the girls ever aspire towards a university education, and typically their life plan was to graduate from elementary, maybe attend high school, and then raise their children.

So, yes, overpopulation is a big problem in sub-Saharan Africa because it limits economical advancement and requires thin distribution of resources. But, we also need to recognize how overpopulation affects the youth - both boys and girls. Sure, overpopulation should be tackled for the sake of the countries' economies, but it should especially be tackled so these young girls can have dreams outside of motherhood, so these young boys are raised in a culture that respects men and women equally.

This is an outdated concept.
Having less children to have a higher standard of living is basically "instant gratification".
Choosing more children and living in relative poverty is "delayed gratification."
In a nutshell, if a couple has 0-1 children, they will have more money for themselves when young but when they're older and unable to work, they'll die of starvation or sickness. Since no one will finance their retirement.
If they have 4-5 kids, they'll be poor until the kids grow up, and then the kids give a small % of their pay for their parent's retirement.
Now just imagine the whole country is one big family. Because that's exactly how it works. If you believe that the money you paid all your life for your own retirement is saved, waiting for you, you're an idiot! At the time of your retirement, you will be paid directly from current taxes. Young (working) people support everyone else in the country through taxes. That's how it always was, we don't save money.
Developed countries now depend on immigration, and that's the only way at the moment, to survive unsustainable birthrates.
In another nutshell, you can not do anything unsustainably in life. Unsustainability is at the core of the collapse of every system.
Cheers.

Your ideological prejudices have made nonsense of this video, which ought to have been informative.
1. You complain that "subsaharan Africa" was a generalizing term for very diverse societies. So was "native American". So what? Generalizations are not nonsense, they are generalizations, and are necessary for understanding some general phenomena. As you ought to know, as exponents of scientific method.
2. You don't bother to mention how much Ethiopia's birthrate has gone down, thanks to what you describe as specially good new policies; only the decline in child mortality. In fact, Ethiopia's birthrate has gone down in the last 50 years by basically the same amount you show for all of subsaharan Africa, about 30%.

3. You blame colonial rule as one of the causes of Africa's continued high fertility and population growth in contrast to other continents. This is opposite to what the evidence shows.

The birthrate reduction and population growth slowdown has gone much better on the Indian subcontinent, where there was much longer colonial rule - 200 years, compared to 80 in subsaharan Africa. Also reduced much better in the Americas, where the societies were formed primarily by a colonial rule that started five hundred years ago and lasted 150-300 years; even in South America, it is down to basically replacement levels. The Arab Islamic countries, where there was the least length or depth of colonial rule, has done second to worst, after subsaharan Africa, in reducing birthrates. Your bias apparently didn't allow you to report or perhaps even notice these facts, which are the facts that are the obvious first ones to look at for making a statement like yours.
4. It might have made at least some logical sense if you had blamed the problem on Western humanitarians, from missionaries to government aid programs, and the medicine they brought. You neglect to do even that, presumably because it would have required a lot of argumentation to stop it from seeming to undermine your political purposes.

Cool thought experiment to demonstrate power of having kids later:
Suppose all people live to 100. Suppose in Country A all women have 2 kids at age 20 and no more. In Country B all women have 2 kids at age 25 and no more.


In Country A, at any given time there are 5 generations of people alive. In Country B there are only 4. Country B has achieved a 20% reduction in population with every single family having exactly the same number of kids as in Country A, merely delaying having them by 5 years.

In poorer and less-developed areas of the world, it makes sense for nature to favor a higher birth rate than the more sustained and modernized civilizations.  There are more "hands" available to try and find work or sustenance for the family as a whole, much like how many farmers and ranchers lived throughout the 1800's and early 1900's in the US.  Having more children also increases your odds for passing on your bloodline in more hostile conditions.. be it regional weather, government, or ecology.  We must remember, humans are animals too, and we are subject to the same laws of natural selection.

Overpopulation is driven by the overproduction and overabundance of food. Around the world today, poverty and malnutrition are fueled by social inequality.

Think about that for a minute. Following the reasoning of @Kurzgesagt and the scientific community, people can spring into existence without any available food. That's bullshit.

Since you like thought experiments so damn much, here's one for you:

A hypothetical, healthy weight woman is kept in isolation and fed a diet that precisely meets her metabolic and nutritional needs, not one calorie more or less. Aside from the psychological stress of the situation, that theoretical woman will survive. Now imagine that she's artificially inseminated and conceives. As her pregnancy advances, no additional food is provided. What happens?

Answer: Either she'll naturally miscarry due to nutritional stress, or both her and the baby will die. (Most likely the former.)

However, @Kurzgesagt and leaders in the scientific and economic communities want you to believe (on no evidence) that the woman would survive and give birth to a healthy baby, but would then begin to starve.

Again, bullshit!

Africa is going through the same process that every other continent has experienced in the past. In the late 19th and early 20th century Europe was the continent going throgh explosive population growth. Then Asia and Latin American had their population booms in the mid-20th century, and now it's Africa's turn.

This population boom is largely the result of the stunning success in lowering child mortality. In 1980 all but 5 countries in Africa had mortality rates above 10%, today only a handful of countries still do. Fertility rates fall more slowly than mortality ones, and all the children who would otherwise have died are now reaching adulthood and having children of their own. With child mortality at lower levels and rampant urbanization, the next generation of Africans will have less children, and population growth will stabilise and then begin to decline.

This assumption can be proved false with an understanding of how evolution by natural selection works. I refer you to the arguments of Garrett Hardin, who explained that voluntary efforts in population control always fail because the “responsible” people who limit their births get out-bred and replaced by the “irresponsible” people, who continue to reproduce rapidly. Whatever had enabled the responsible people to restrain themselves disappears from the gene pool. Man’s intelligence, being without peer on Earth, has prevented any natural predator from keeping his numbers in check. Furthermore, the “tragedy of the commons” noticed by Hardin makes any voluntary effort in population control fail, sooner or later. Man must supply his own predation.

i gotta say, Kurzgesagt - In a Nutshell... you guys are bold in this day of YouTube censorship. This is a breath of fresh, honest air. I know you're not racist. I'm honestly glad that someone has taken it upon themselves to try to tackle the difficult questions and problems plaguing our societies and world. I know there are no easy answers to why things like this happened, or on how to fix them, but if we can try to look at things from an objective, NON-RACIST point of view, ignore nasty things like ethnic cleansing and eugenics, and focus our attention on addressing needs of the people and environment with better education, agriculture and medical care, we just might be able to stabilize these types of places and help them become prosperous, too.

The only things I disagree with on the video is that Africa also has to deal with droughts throughout the Sahel region (from Senegal to Ethiopia) on a regular basis, particularly since 1960. This is what helped instigate some of the strife, made existing strife far worse, and just acted as a threat multiplier on increasing societal instability. Let's not forget the AIDS epidemic that has ravaged the entire continent and beyond, with countless children and adults dying from the disease that could have otherwise helped their nations and continent as productive members of society if they had not been cut down by the epidemic (or warfare or famine).

I try to get figures on life expectancy at conception, but, so far, I just have to make guesses. I would 'guess' in ancient Mesopotamia, at the dawn of civilization, a woman that conceived a child would have only a 1 in 10 chance of seeing that child live to 12 yrs old, and very few indeed lived beyond 60. The chances of even the mother surviving childbirth were not all that good. When people talk about returning to the life of our ancestors who lived 8000-10,000 yrs ago because they erroneously assume that "they lived in near idyllic conditions," the situation in reality is even more stark. Today, we use phrases like "before the patriarchy ruined everything;" but what they don't realize is that even living to 12 yrs old at that remote time was very very difficult. Humanity has made huge progress over the millennia that many people today totally discount and apparently consider worthless, assuming, apparently, that most people live isolated, fragmented, and miserable lives. Nothing could be further from the truth. Compared with our distant ancestors, we live in a paradise.

I'm studying geopolitics for my B.S. (senior year). Pretty much everything in here is right on the money. One caveat though, if a state's birthrate drops too quickly, then, in roughly 50 years time, the economic (and therefore political) situation will be tenuous because you'll have an inverted growth chart where the elderly outnumber the youth. The productive youth need to burden the responsibility of elderly healthcare. The growth chart on the right at 3:18 is healthy. But when there's an inverted growth chart (like with Japan, for example) there's too few able-bodied people to shoulder the burden. Lower infant mortality and less birthrate overall have to cancel each other out. The goal isn't necessarily to lower the population but to give more resources (ie education, less corrupt gvt, businesses friendly environment, health care) to the population already there.

India would still have its caste system, Aztecs descendants would still be mass sacrificing individuals in the hundreds daily, and Africa would still be almost entirely tribal primitives selling one another to coastal slave markets. Before colonization, The Great Zimbabwe was the largest sub-Saharan structure ever built. That's the highest they achieved. Even after the discovery of the New World and the introduction of the cassava and other crops from the rest of the world, they still struggled to feed themselves. Even to this day! They perpetuate this cycle. Blaming anyone outside of Africa is no longer just ignorant at this point, it's an outright lie typically wielded to serve very specific political agendas. "Africans are never responsible for themselves, they're poor victims of everything and everyone throughout all history." The reality is that we're not all equal any more than all varieties of any animal species is. The Africans struggle because they're the bottom of the human barrel. Sorry, the fact that you’re just assuming overpopulation is actually a real problem (it’s largely a malthusian myth which in many ways emerged out of the eugenics movement) and a lot of what’s being taken for granted here is purely ideology disguised as science. The entire US population for example could fit in like, an area the size of new hampshire if that area was all about as dense as new york city. Resources like food and housing are largely built from renewable materials (give or take the limits of earth’s ability to replenish its soil/trees/etc) so we don’t actually have to be all that worried about running out of them. There’s plenty to go around, the problem is in how it’s distributed.
Look I’m sure that wasn’t the intention (or maybe it was idk) but it’s extremely irresponsible to be pushing ideas like this, a lot of nazi and white supremacist ideology is rooted on false framings like overpopulation which can be debunked fairly easily as misunderstandings of what the earth and people are capable of. There aren’t too many people and we’re not anywhere close to wherever that limit would be if there even is one, which there may not be if we organized our resources well enough. Once, the Americans tried to play god in China, they didn't want them to become a world power so to try and halt population they spread awful and violent tactics under the guise of helping China. They introduced ultrasound machines that could determine the sex of the baby, but didn't use them for health reasons, they just scanned millions of poor peasants, and then they hung up posters prompting people to abort all female fetuses (often very violent words like "if it's a girl, it doesn't matter if you have to beat it out, just get rid of it"). This was massively effective because peasants in China marry off their girls to other families, so they always wish for boys becuase they need the help with their farming. Now they had a way to get rid of the girls, and of course the one-child policy only made it worse. China is still traumatized and have way way too many men.

Unnecessary and controversial rant that hopes to make people think, I guess:
"Many of these nations suffered under colonization"? I'm not too sure about that...
While I totally agree that in some instances European powers did horroble things, like what Leopold of Belgium's private army did in Congo, though overall in most instances the colonization was, if not bloodless, kind of close to that, or at least without unnecessary atrocities, though I understand that this isn't a great way to summarize an extremely complex set of events that stretched through several centuries with several protagonists and in an area larger than Europe.
But what we can say seems fairly certain is what the data shows us: countries that have been colonized for the most time and most intensively, like South Africa and Equatorial Guinea, have had and have the largest and most stable economies, and, conversely, the opposite is true for countries like South Sudan, the D. R. of Congo and most other countries that are in the interior and thus were later contacted and that didn't manage to trasform themselves into a seemingly stable fiscal paradise like Rwanda, or countries like Mozambique, that had a communist revolution.
The thing is, it seems like many people there didn't and often still don't seem to share the values that we Westerners hold, that seem to be necessary to create a civilization that truly rises from the poverty typical of a pre industial nation, like individualism, democracy, capitalism... and while you could say that we could simply have left them alone, I'm not sure they would have enjoyed it, and neither would we, as a bigger market is just better for everyone, as no, there is nothing that can point to the fact that had we left them alone, they would have developed like we did in an absolutely miraculous way, something that too many modern people take for granted, but it's much more probable that they would have stagnated like they always did and have done.
Does this make colonization ethical? I don't know, it depends on how you see it, I guess...
Did it make Africans worse off economically? Well, you could make a case for the ethnic tensions from within, but accondiscending to everyone's demands, nobody would be able to remember all these nations, for there are so many, and countries like Belgium and Luxembourg seem to be doing pretty well... thus, in general, no, if an African state crashed post independence the first cause you should point a finger to is, I'd say, their corruption and their mistakes, and to me what has happened recently seems mostly like a watered down repetition of Africa's pre colonial history, from the Bantu expansion and tribal wars for slaves to Mugabe's Zimbabwe and the various civil wars.
Now, I know that not taking responsibilities is really tempting, not that that's what always happens, but those who look for scapegoats only create a rape and revenge narrative that is going to tear them apart in a climactic rise of genocidal hatred that has showed itself time and again in Nazi Germany just like before the Rwandan massacres.
Hope I have provided a not too simplified rant about a sentence in a video as I had nothing better to do being ill. In the end, keep up the good work Kurzgesagt, love your videos.

There are a few things I believe are misleading in this video and I would like to adress it.


1. First of all the video was comparing Asian countries (esp. Bangladesh) and Sub-saharan Africa, implying that the scale of population growth is somewhat comparable. This video failed to mention however, that SSA already went through a population increase outclassing any of the mentioned Asian countries. In Bangladesh for example, the population increased from 29M. in 1901 to 161M. in 2016 (increase of ~450%) whereas the population of Africa increased from 125M. in 1913 to 1321M. in 2018 (increase of >900%). This population is then projected to increase further as mentioned in the video.


2. The role of colonialism and wars is used in this video to (partly) justify the different development of SSA in comparison to Asia. How exactly he justifies this is all but clear, since many of the Asian countries (including those he mentioned), were also colonized often to a far greater extent and for a much longer span of time (India, Bangladesh, the Philippines (video); Vietnam, Indonesia etc.) . Adding to that, countries like South Korea and Vietnam also went through crippling wars and still didn't end up like SSA. Then there is the argument of ethnic conflict in the often arbitrarily created colonial states. However many of the states in Asia also faced this problem (Indonesia, Malaysia, Indochina, the British Raj, the Philippines etc.).


3. The impact of reducing child mortality is used in this video as a reason for the decline of birthrates. While this may be true, this decline isn't the immidiate effect of it. The immidiate effect is a population boom , since more children survive until adulthood. The decline of birthrates, is then effect that can happen sooner or later and in the case of Africa it is clearly later.


4. Ignoring the aging population: While this video mentions that the population ages, it doesn't address the fact, that the population continues to grow, even if the fertility rate drops below replacement level.

I am from a developing country (Honduras) and the same thing happens over here. Around 60% of the population is under the age of 21. It is common to see underaged girls pregnant, specially in extremely poor settlements. By the time these girls are 25 (a productive age were they might start to contribute to society) they’ve already plugged in more demand of resources into the system in the form of 3 to 4 new kids.This obviously puts a huge burden to the productive part of the population which has to pay for hospitals, roads, schools, housing, food, etc. It is imposible to cover all this demand if those that pay the taxes that go into these investments are fewer than the part of the population that generate that demand. As a result of this unattended necessity we see the symptoms of a poor society.

Most honduran citizens see poverty and are inclined to blame the government and politicians for not fixing it. Although corruption and uncaring politicians are an important part of the problem, they are not the root of the problem. Although it is a “poverty trap” type of situation where we don’t have the resources to kickstart the solution, it is clear we must first change our demographic structure using the solutions that have been proven to help fix the problem in other countries facing the same challenges, as exposed in this video. One clear example is our neighbor country Costa Rica which heavily invested in education in the 80s. They now have a more balanced demographic structure. Costa Rica has half of Honduras’ population and yet they have a 5x higher GDP / capita = much less poverty.
But when you say investment in African resources, just like in Asia, I suppose you mean responsible investments, so that no sweatshops or other abuses happen, as in Asia

I live in Ethiopia and I was actually discussing a tough housing project with my partner little before watching this video. Over the months, we architecture students have gotten to the point of fighting when talking about how to make houses for the poorest slum dwellers in the city. THERE'S JUST SO MANY PEOPLE. And they just keep increasing, not just by natural birth but also by rural to urban migration from the 80% rural population. I took part in the T2D rural to urban migration project and found that what exists is not just a housing problem. I participated in an AU youth conference and found that it's not just a social/tribal/ethnic issue at hand either. The fear, stubbornness, and selfishness that aggravates everything on every level of this society are not unique to this part of the world. But it manifested itself on an intense level here.

(p.s. You can subscribe to my channel to follow up on videos in which I talk about this context.)

So, thank you Kurzgesagt for even beginning to tackle a problem that feels like it's taken the form of an unbudging monster. Don't be afraid to state the problems and factors that I know you found in your research when it comes to the Sub-Saharan context.

This worries me in relation to human space expansion. I figured, "oh humans will be on a new planet, they'll have hella kids", but it's not that simple. I'm no expert, I'm in a fairly different field, but I have studied a lot of history and social science. In my uneducated opinion, poverty has almost no causal link to birthrate. There are way too many confounding variables (cultural pressure, child mortality rates, etc.). When we expand, we will still have a culture that supports fewer kids (most likely), and child mortality likely will still be lower in much harsher environments. Plus, I wouldn't want to raise a family in a harsh environment like Mars. So is there going to be a huge population crash whenever we decide to become interplanetary?

So, the world faces two problems: whether growing almost under the Replacement Fertility Rate (Europe, Japan, etc.) or growing way beyond it sustainability (Africa, etc.) . Peddling to Africa exactly the same solutions that now are the headache of Europe (etc.) doesn't seem to be the best idea, the problem being (yes, exactly) we don't know how to have the best of both worlds (the best quality of life with the "right amount" of stable population growth). By the way "taking the youth of the poor countries" via immigration to "solve the problems of the richer countries" is neither empathic nor good, as it simply condemns the poor countries to handle the loss of the be best of their youth (and by the way, provokes a swath of other social conundrums) as they are, too, adopting contraceptive methods, regardless. May be there isn't a perfect solution or balance or if there is, we can't handle it (under the current sociological, ideological, cultural paradigms). And we are not even touching the nightmare of the enviromental, ecological, climated issues we face (and that won't go away one way or the other).

There is an argument that fewer children, better healthcare, and contraceptives do not cause wealth, wealth causes these things; that you have the causation on this issue backwards.

In poor countries, the difference between having a 7th kid versus just having 6 is not a big difference in lifestyle, so many opt to have an additional child. In fact, since the jobs available to late teens pay similarly to jobs available to adults in these countries, and younger children can help with the family farm or the family store, having a child might increase the net income of a household. In a wealthy country, where parents are expected to do things like pay for college, or at least try to help out, the difference between having a second kid and just having one is possibly more than $100,000 over the course of a lifetime, and households are likely never to increase their income from having a child, as the child moves out before contributing financially to the family.

The difference in wealth levels between the former European colonies in Africa and the former European colonies in Africa could be explained in part by property rights and free markets. The more people are secure in their ability to invest in themselves and their children, the more the wealth of their societies have grown, and the fewer children and better healthcare they have as a result. The less secure people are in their property rights, the less incentive they have to produce and invest, and the less wealth their societies have.

I feel as though something is missing from this video - namely an argument for why it's such a necessity to curtail Sub-Saharan African population growth in the first place. As presented in the video, the argument goes something like:
1) The African Population is about to increase dramatically.
2) African countries tend to be poor.
3) Therefore it is imperative to get the African population under control.


But (3) doesn't necessarily directly follow from (1) or (2). There's a missing piece to the puzzle. Why is (3) not, for example, "therefore it is imperative to jump-start Sub-Saharan Africa's economic development?" The video acts as if points (1) and (2) inherently mean that SSA's population growth is inherently unsustainable and the solution is to reduce birth rates. It may be that this is true, but there's no argument in the video to indicate it. As is, the video simply operates under the assumption that the world needs fewer poor people, and the solution is to decrease the surplus population.

There is currently a problem with warfare, post-colonization traumas, heterogeneous populations forced to live together because of random borders, diseases, lack of education, a couple of natural disasters etc. You know, the issues most countries go through.
All these factors/stressors lead will (and probably have) lead to higher child births in ANY population. Reduce the stressors by helping them more, and everything else will be better - you might even tackle the fear of overpopulation at the same time. There are many examples of this working well.
Africa needs to keep the slow and steady progress, it often takes multiple revolutions to get to peace anyways, so it's gonna be a bumpy ride. Changing things too fast will however backlash.

It’s also important to consider long term how reductions in population growth especially rapid reduction
Affects the nations age demographics.

True the in the short run the country will receive what has been called the demographic dividend. As the country has a great many working age people and fewer children dependents.

But in the long run this situation obviously get reversed with a greater number of old dependents and not enough young workers to support them. See much the developed world today for what that looks like.

Ideally the demographic dividend is well invested and the economy grows and so the fewer workers are able to take care of more old dependents.
But this is by no means a guarantee, by many estimates the Chinese may have squandered their demographic dividend, on a great many with little returns.

🤔 The overpopulation argument doesn't really stand scrutiny, nor does the "colonists killed Africa" argument. All other former colonies are better off, regardless of domination harshness (take a look at Ireland, ethnic heterogeneity (have a look at India), or foreign aid (Cuba does surprisingly well despite having suffered quite a lot of embargoes and lack of foreign aid).
All in all, it seems that, counter intuitively, foreign aid did screw up Africa far more than colonisation could. Opening borders to a ton of African workers also screwed up Africa's capability to grow, by leeching off its youth. Finally, despite being resource rich, Africa struggles to become rich and industrialized, and this can only be due to strictly African cultural and political habits: irreconcilable tribalism and state overcorruption.
Lastly, Africa did manage to grow anyway, albeit very slowly. Still, we can see they are taking the right direction, and with all the pandemics assaulting the continent, it's highly unlikely that Earth ever experiences the alleged overpopulation boogeyman.

First (ish)

Seriously. Why are we making videos like this? This topic was a nightmare. How do you talk about a continent as diverse as Africa, to explain larger trends? Not only is there a wide variety of sources, experts disagree with each other on what they can predict about the future. So the time we took to rewrite this script over and over was insane.


Still, there is no chance this video won’t make people angry, on all sides of this issue. Some may not agree with the conclusions we have come to. Some will think there are other aspects we could and should have mentioned. Or lament that we generalized too much.


But we had to generalize or this video would just have become a hour-long documentary. And we think the topic is too important to not discuss it.


So we read a lot and talked too many experts with very different opinions and interpretations. Also we tried to prepare our sources in a way that walks you through our thought process and helps you to make up your own mind.


This video was sponsored by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation as part of a Grant. They did not take part in the production of the video though.


Sources and comments: https://sites.google.com/view/sourcesoverpopulationandafrica
